awd_titl_txt: CS-LISTEN: Computer Science Learning and Inquiring with Students Through Equity Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
University of California - San Diego's Center for Research on Educational Equity, Assessment and Teaching Excellence (CREATE) and Education Studies Department will develop the Computer Science: Learning and Inquiring with Students Through Equity Networks (CS-LISTEN) as a Pre-K12 Pathways project.  In K12 education, the use of students as change partners is rare.  This project will use a Youth Participatory Action Research methodology to gather student voices around CS4All and equity. This project will leverage an existing research-practice partnership formed around student co-research, communities of practice, and network improvement communities to rectify the lack of student participatory-design shortcomings in student pathways.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Computer Science: Listening and Inquiring with Students through Equity Networks (CS-LISTEN) uses youth participatory action research (YPAR) methodology to study and improve broadening participation in high school computer science courses and pathways. UC San Diego researchers from the Center for Research on Educational Equity, Assessment and Teaching Excellence (CREATE) and Education Studies worked closely with four districts San Diego Unified (2nd largest in California), Sweetwater Union High School District (largest secondary only district in California), Vista Unified School District (VUSD), and Escondido Union High School District (approximately 22,000 students) where they cultivated teams of high school student researchers and their educators to study why more students from diverse backgrounds were not taking computer science courses. 

In total, 11 high schools, 15 high school educators, 16 teams of students that constituted a total of 193 public high school students participated over a two-year period. 

The work of CS-LISTEN and its district, school, and teacher partners placed youth in the driver's seat of school reform. The project encouraged the students into leadership positions to conduct innovative research and action cycles to unearth barriers to CS enrollment among underrepresented students (e.g. racial minorities, women, etc.). The project operated as a research-practice partnership (RPP) where findings were revealed to school site and district-level administrators and shared across with career and workforce readiness county leadership as well. In the end, three of the four districts increased their CS enrollments significantly over the grant period. 

Intellectual Merit: 

CS-LISTEN contributed to the overall understanding of incorporating youth participatory action research (YPAR) inside an RPP to deepen the field's understanding, through students' perspectives, of barriers to and potential innovations for broadening engagement in K12 CS pathways. CS-LISTEN identified, examined, and tackled through iterative research-action cycles, issues that student-led research surfaced in terms of content/pedagogy, race/gender/cultural concerns, power/political concerns, etc. Through student-led collective work, we learned much about how students need to be reached, what messages about broadening participation resonate with youth today (and which do not, given the stigmas/perceptions that students discovered still follow the field into high schools today), and how important it is that they feel a sense of community and engagement when outreached to and while inside their CS courses. In the end, we also learned that students can definitely be part of the solution, but also that adults have a key role to play in bringing student ideas to life, systemically. District and school administrators were essential to increasing access by eliminating prerequisites, hiring teachers, championing courses (even when enrollments could be lower than ideal budgetarily), and using the resources of the district (websites, parent networks, etc.) to advertise their CS courses widely and earlier to younger students. See the CS-LISTEN website (https://cslisten.ucsd.edu/) for examples of each of the CS-LISTEN high school team YPAR research posters, as well as two brief videos on the YPAR and action cycles each student team completed. 

Broader Impact:

The broader impact of CS-LISTEN has been the steady removal of barriers to diverse and engaging computing courses and pathways for ALL students in the four districts the students teams worked within. Key developments occurred in recruitment practices that were more effective for underrepresented minority, low-income and female students. Secondarily, CS-LISTEN furthered our understanding of the potential impact of student voice research, and specifically the use of YPAR as a methodology, on investigating and catalyzing institutional change. 


 

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2024
Modified by: Susan Yonezawa
